XVII Hydrogen atom

The Hydrogen atom consists of an electron of mass me and negative charge -e, and a nucleus, which is a proton of positive charge e and mass mpâ‰ˆ1836â¢me. The total Hamiltonian of electron and proton is given by

where the potential energy is the Coulomb energy of the two attracting charges.

XVII.4 Energies

Since n=-Î¼2â¢Eâ¢e24â¢Ï€â¢Îµ0â¢â„ the energy levels of the Hydrogen atom only depend on the principal quantum number n but not on l or m:

En=-Î¼2â¢(e24â¢Ï€â¢Îµ0â¢â„)2â¢1n2. (341)

The energies can also be written as En=-Ryâ¢1n2 where Ry=e28â¢Ï€â¢Ïµ0â¢a0=13.6 eV is the so-called Rydberg energy and a0=4â¢Ï€â¢Ïµ0â¢â„2Î¼â¢e2â‰ˆ0.53Ã—10-10m is called the Bohr radius.

The lowest energy level has energy E1=-Ry=-13.6 eV. For energy E>0, the electrons are not bound to the nucleus. Hence the Rydberg energy is the amount of energy required to release the electron from the nucleus (this process is called ionisation).

XVII.5 Spectral lines

The electron can change from one energy level n to another level nâ€² if it absorbs or emits a photon which carries the right amount of energy â„â¢Ï‰=En-Enâ€². This gives rise to discrete spectral lines. The most important lines are grouped into series, such as the Lyman series (nâ€²=1), the Balmer series (nâ€²=2), and the Paschen series (nâ€²=3).

XVII.6 Degeneracy

For each n the allowed values of l are 0,1,2,â€¦,n-1, and for each l there are 2â¢l+1 allowed values of m. Hence, the degeneracy of each energy level En is âˆ‘l=1n-1(2â¢l+1)=n2. Later we will learn that the electron has an intrinsic degree of freedom called spin so that the degeneracy of each energy level is really 2â¢n2. On the other hand we neglected small perturbations which lift the degeneracy and result in a fine structure of the energy levels. They will be discussed in the third year module PHYS321, Atomic & Nuclear Physics.

XVII.7 Atomic orbitals

The wavefunctions

Ïˆnâ¢lâ¢mâ¢(ğ«)=Ylâ¢mâ¢(Î¸,Ï•)â¢Fn,lâ¢(2â¢r/(nâ¢a0)) (342)

of the hydrogen atom are also called atomic orbitals. The azimuthal quantum number is denoted by a symbol s for l=0, p for l=1, d for l=2, and f for l=3. These symbols are then preceded by the principal wavenumber n, so that orbitals are denoted by 1s, 2s, 2p, 3s, 3p, 3d etc.

XVII.7.1 Ground state

The ground state is associated with the spherically symmetric orbital 1s with energy E1=-Ry,

Ïˆ100â¢(ğ«)=1Ï€â¢a03â¢e-r/a0. (343)

The probability density to find the particle in a shell of width dâ¢r at distance r is given by

Pâ¢(r)=4â¢Ï€â¢r2â¢|Ïˆ100â¢(ğ«)|2=4â¢r2a03â¢e-2â¢r/a0. (344)

This probability density is maximal at r=a0.

XVII.7.2 First excited state

The first excited state has energy E2=-Ry/4 and is fourfold degenerate. It consists of the one 2s orbital and three 2p orbitals. The 2s orbital (l=0, m=0) is spherical symmetric,

Ïˆ200â¢(ğ«)=18â¢Ï€â¢a03â¢(1-r2â¢a0)â¢e-r/(2â¢a0). (345)

The 2p orbitals are not spherical symmetric,

Ïˆ210â¢(ğ«) = 132â¢Ï€â¢a03â¢ra0â¢cosâ¡Î¸â¢e-r/(2â¢a0), (346)
Ïˆ21,Â±1â¢(ğ«) = Â±164â¢Ï€â¢a03â¢ra0â¢sinâ¡Î¸â¢e-r/(2â¢a0)Â±iâ¢Ï•. (347)

XVII.7.3 Second excited state

The second excited state has energy E3=-Ry/9 and is nine-fold degenerate. It consists of one 3s orbital, three 3p orbitals and five 3d orbitals.

XVII.8 Application: The Zeeman effect

We consider the hydrogen atom in a constant magnetic field ğ=Bzâ¢ğ¤, which points into the z direction. The total magnetic moment of the electron is [see Eqs.Â (274) and (280)]

ğ¦^=-e2â¢meâ¢(ğ‹^+2â¢ğ’^). (348)

The interaction energy of the magnetic moment with the magnetic field is

V^B=-ğâ‹…ğ¦^=eâ¢Bz2â¢meâ¢(L^z+2â¢S^z). (349)

The total Hamiltonian is given by

H^=ğ©^22â¢Î¼-e24â¢Ï€â¢Îµ0â¢|ğ«|+V^B. (350)

The SchrÃ¶dinger equation Eâ¢Ïˆ=Hâ¢Ïˆ is solved by

Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢lâ†‘ = Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢l(ğ«)(10),(ms=1/2) (351)
Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢lâ†“ = Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢l(ğ«)(01),(ms=-1/2). (352)

where Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢lâ¢(ğ«) are the orbital wavefunctions of the hydrogen atom. These functions are eigenfunctions of V^B:

V^Bâ¢Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢l,msâ¢(ğ«)=(m+2â¢ms)â¢Î¼Bâ¢Bzâ¢Ïˆnâ¢mâ¢l,msâ¢(ğ«), (353)

where Î¼B=eâ¢â„/2â¢me is the Bohr magneton. However, the degeneracy of the eigenvalues is now lifted,

Enâ¢mâ¢l=-e28â¢Ï€â¢Ïµ0â¢a0â¢1n2+(m+2â¢ms)â¢Î¼Bâ¢Bz. (354)

The splitting of the levels depends linearly on the strength Bz of the magnetic field.

The splitting of the orbital energies can be observed in the spectral lines of the hydrogen atom. This is called the Zeeman effect. The observable spectral lines is restricted by selection rules: m can only change by -1, 0, or 1, because of properties of the emitted photons. Since ms cannot change, the spin splitting is not observed in the normal Zeeman effect.
